Day 17.Title: YUVAi: Global Youth Challenge - Grand Finale
Day 17.Name: Sh. Mohammed Y. Safirulla K, Director, IndiaAI Mission, Ministry of Electronics & Information Technology
Day 17.name: Deepak Bagla, Mission Director, Atal Innovation Mission (AIM)
Day 17.name_1: Ivana Bartoletti, Vice-President, Global Chief Privacy and  AI Governance Officer, Wipro (TBC)
Day 17.Description_1: This session will feature presentations by selected teams across three panels, showcasing their ideas and solutions. Each segment will be followed by jury interactions and questions, enabling deeper evaluation, feedback, and discussion.

Day 17.Title: Democratizing AI Resources: Research Pathways to Open, Equitable Access
Day 17.Name: Mr. Arun Jain, Intellect Design Arena Ltd.
Day 17.name: Mr. Jaswinder Sodhi, HSBC India
Day 17.Description_1: The session examines how to democratise AI across India's social and economic landscape so that people, communities, industry, and government benefit safely. It promotes a platform approach beyond models, offering shared building blocks for data, compute, skills, evaluation, and trusted deployment. Discussion covers privacy-preserving data collaboration, India-ready multilingual benchmarks, cost-efficient optimisation, and responsible, auditable architectures with policy controls, centring human-AI collaboration for judgment, empathy, intent, and accountability across sectors and diverse populations.

Day 17.Title: Democratizing AI for the Last Mile:Language, Access and Trust at Scale
Day 17.Name: Amitabh Nag, Digital India Bhashini Division
Day 17.name: Brijendra Kumar, KPMG
Day 17.Description_1: The session advances the conversation from democratizing AI access to enabling meaningful last-mile adoption, where inclusion, usability, and public trust define real impact. It explores how language AI and foundation models can serve as shared national digital infrastructure, powering governance and cultural services at scale. Emphasizing trust-by-design, it highlights transparent, accountable, human-centric AI and collaboration across industry, government platforms, and public institutions to responsibly scale inclusive AI.

Day 17.Title: Secure AI Development: Understanding the Security Risks and Developing Advice and Global Technical Standards
Day 17.Name: Mr Oliver Brooks, UK Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office (FCDO)
Day 17.name: Mr Oliver Jones, UK AI Security Institute (AISI)
Day 17.Description_1: Discover how the UK Government is working with global partners to understand the risks and shape the future of secure AI. The UK AI Security Institute (AISI) will introduce the key findings from its Frontier AI Trends Report. The session will showcase the work of the UK government, including the NCSC, to collaborate with global industry, governments and academia to produce security requirements and drive the development of the world's first global AI security standard.

Day 17.Title: AI for Health Innovations
Day 17.Name: Dr. Ajay Bakshi, NeuranceAI
Day 17.name: Dr. Dileep Raman, Cloud  Physician
Day 17.name_2: Dr. Taruna Madan Gupta, Indian Council of Medical Research
Day 17.Description_1: This panel will bring together leaders from healthcare, technology, research, and innovation ecosystems to discuss how Artificial Intelligence is transforming health innovation. The discussion will explore AI-driven solutions across diagnostics, medical devices, public health, clinical decision-making, and health systems strengthening, with a strong focus on real world deployment, scalability, ethics, and regulation in emerging markets like India.
Day 17.Description_4: Mr. Sandeep Nailwal, Polygon Foundation and  Founder Blockchain For Impact BFI

Day 17.Title: AI and the Future of Creativity: Power, Originality, and Public Imagination
Day 17.Name: Divya Siddarth, Collective Intelligence Project
Day 17.name: Nabiha Syed, Mozilla Foundation
Day 17.Description_1: This session explores the paradox of AI-driven creativity—its power to democratize expression while endangering artists and cultural workers. Panelists will address authenticity, consent, and fairness in creative AI, equitable access for global creators, and safeguards against manipulation. Discussions will focus on AI's impact on livelihoods, data ethics, and open ecosystems, producing 5–7 guiding principles on provenance, consent, remuneration, transparency, and cultural infrastructure for global AI and creativity policy frameworks.

Day 17.Title: AI for ALL Challenge Overview and Panel discussion on 'Leveraging AI to drive Development Objectives in the Global South
Day 17.Name: Mr. Amitabh Nag, CEO, Bhashini
Day 17.name: Ms. Kavita Bhatia, COO, IndiaAI
Day 17.name_1: Mr. Tomoyuki Yamada, Senior Director of Office for STI & DX, JICA​
Day 17.name_2: Mr. Karan Mohla, General Partner, B Capital
Day 17.name_3: Mr. Ramanan Ramanathan, Mission Governing Board, IndiaAI
Day 17.Description_1: The AI for ALL: Global Impact Challenge showcase will start with the journey of the Challenge, from its launch in October to the selection of 20 standout finalists from a highly competitive global pool. The session will also feature a dynamic, jury-led panel exploring how AI can unlock transformative development across the Global South. Senior voices from industry, venture capital, and the development sector will share real-world applications of AI, while diving into critical themes such as equitable access, responsible governance, and inclusive deployment at scale.
Day 17.Description_4: Mr. Mudit Kumar, Co-Founder and COO, Ideabaaz
Day 17.Description_7: Ms. Courtney O'Donnell, Global Impact Lead, Anthropic

Day 17.Title: AI for ALL Top 20 Finalists Showcase: Live Pitches and Jury Q&A
Day 17.Name: Mr. Tomoyuki Yamada, Senior Director of Office for STI & DX, JICA​
Day 17.name: Mr. Karan Mohla, General Partner, B Capital
Day 17.name_1: Mr. Ramanan Ramanathan, Mission Governing Board, IndiaAI
Day 17.name_2: Mr. Mudit Kumar, Co-Founder and COO, Ideabaaz
Day 17.name_3: Ms. Courtney O'Donnell, Global Impact Lead, Anthropic
Day 17.Description_1: This session will feature the Top 20 finalists of the AI for ALL Challenge presenting their solutions to an esteemed jury. Each team will outline the problem they are addressing, the AI technology used, their business model, and the impact created. Based on these pitches, the jury will evaluate and select the Top 10 teams, who will be announced as winners of the AI for ALL: Global Impact Challenge.

Day 17.Title: Safe and Trusted AI: Standardization in the age of LLMs, Generative and Agentic AI
Day 17.Name: Mr. Abhishek Aggarwal, Ministry of Electronics & IT, GoI
Day 17.name: Mr. Ashish Tewari, Infosys
Day 17.name_2: Mr. Sridhar Chimalakonda, IIT (IIT) Tirupati, India; Adjunct Faculty, University of Waterloo, Canada
Day 17.name_3: Mr. Tim McGarr, British Standards Institution (BSI)
Day 17.Description_1: The rapid deployment of LLMs, Generative, and Agentic AI offers immense productivity gains alongside significant concerns. This panel identifies opportunities and challenges in AI adoption, highlighting how standardization enables responsible innovation. Featuring experts from industry, academia, and policy, the session explores the current status of AI standards and the urgent need for further frameworks. The goal is to ensure AI's responsible use for positive societal impact through a collaborative, standardized approach.
Day 17.Description_4: Mrs Reena Garg, Bureau of Indian Standards
Day 17.Description_7: Ms. Gayathri Ekambaram, Tata Consultancy Services

Day 17.Title: Trustworthy AI Investments : Capital Allocations as AI Governance
Day 17.Name: Amir Banifatemi, Cognizant
Day 17.name: Balamaran Ravindran, CeRAI - IIT Madras
Day 17.Description_1: This panel examines how venture capital, sovereign funds, and philanthropy are shaping AI governance, exploring trustworthy AI investment frameworks, transparency in capital flows, and aligning AI innovation with long-term public interest.
Day 17.Description_7: Wan Sie Lee, Info-Communications Media Development Authority (IMDA)

Day 17.Title: Diplomacy and Development in the Era of AI: Turning Innovation into Impact (Hosted by ServiceNow )
Day 17.ROom: Hall No. 3 First Floor - Session Hall 4
Day 17.Name: H.E. Amandeep Singh Gill, Under-Secretary-General and Special Envoy of the United Nations for Digital and Emerging Technologies
Day 17.Description_1: AI has evolved beyond pilot projects to fundamentally transform business operations, workflows, and value creation. As adoption accelerates, leadership faces mounting pressure to pair innovation with strong governance embedded in corporate strategy. Organizations need modern, trust-based frameworks to ensure accountability and responsible decision-making. With rapid growth in markets like India, scaling AI demands the right leadership, operating models, and technical foundations. Robust governance becomes a catalyst, enabling secure, aligned, and confident AI deployment across the enterprise.

Day 17.Title: Global Dialogue on AI Usage-Data for Labour Market Resilience
Day 17.Name: Ambassador Philip Thigo, H.E the President of the Republic of Kenya.
Day 17.name: Bharat Chandar, Stanford Digital Economy Lab, Stanford University
Day 17.name_2: Hector de Rivoire, Microsoft's Office of Responsible AI
Day 17.name_3: Prof. Robert Trager, Oxford Martin AI Governance Initiative at the University of Oxford
Day 17.Description_1: The convening will bring together international economists, AI research organisations, global institutions, think tanks, and delegates from countries attending the AI Impact Summit 2026. As governments develop AI workforce transition strategies, access to local AI usage data is increasingly important. The event will examine why such data matters, what level of granularity is needed, and why countries must have reliable access to it.

Day 17.Title: The NxtWave–OpenAI National Hackathon Grand Finale
Day 17.Name: Bonnie Chatterjee, OpenAI
Day 17.name: Dr. Vineet Joshi, University Grants Commission (UGC), Ministry of Education
Day 17.name_1: Jitin Prasada, Ministry of Commerce and Industry and Ministry of Electronics and IT
Day 17.name_2: Prof. Yogesh Singh, AICTE, Ministry of Education
Day 17.Description_1: This session marks the grand finale of a nationwide AI buildathon initiative, celebrating participation from over 26,000 students across seven states. More than 1,400 teams developed AI solutions through regional buildathons held across Telangana, Andhra Pradesh, Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, Delhi NCR, Rajasthan, and Maharashtra. The session will showcase selected solutions, share key learnings from the programme, and conclude with the felicitation of finalist teams and partners involved.

Day 17.Title: Policies for Social and Economic Resilience in the AI Age: Global South Perspectives
Day 17.Name: Adrian Brown, Windfall Trust
Day 17.name: Kô Goma, Togo Ministry of Public Service Efficiency and Digital Transformation
Day 17.Description_1: Bringing insights from new research, the experts in this session will discuss key recommendations that can guide leaders in navigating labor & economic policymaking and empowering workers in the age of AI. This dialogue will reflect upon how the Global South can build institutional capacity and shape inclusive economic systems to ensure that AI-driven technological change can facilitate shared prosperity.
Day 17.Description_7: Thomas Schneider, Swiss Federal Office of Communications

Day 17.Title: Open-source Tooling for Safe, Secure and Trustworthy AI
Education for Social Empowerment: Building Resilient, Inclusive Learning Systems
Day 17.Name: Jagadish Babu, EkStep Foundation
Day 17.name: Mr. Benjamin Piper, Gates Foundation
Day 17.Description_1: This session explores how education systems can be redesigned to be more inclusive, resilient, and responsive using digital public infrastructure and adaptive learning approaches. Speakers will share field learnings from education reforms, community-led models, and digital interventions that aim to improve equity and learning outcomes at scale
Day 17.Description_4: Ms. Yogita Rana, Govt of Telangana

Day 17.Title: From Algorithms to ASHAs: Implementing Impactful AI at the Grassroots
Day 17.Name: Dr. Anurag Agrawal, Biosciences and Health Research, Ashoka University
Day 17.name: Dr. Aparna Hegde, ARMMAN
Day 17.name_1: Dr. Mithun Kumar Mitra, Department of Physics, IIT Bombay
Day 17.name_2: Dr. Smisha Agarwal, Center for Global Digital Health Innovation (CGDHI)
Day 17.name_3: Urvashi Wattal, Evidence & Impact, Khushi Baby
Day 17.Description_1: India's digital public infrastructure has created unprecedented opportunities to deploy AI in healthcare but scaling solutions beyond pilots remains a challenge. This panel brings together leaders from public health, medicine, and data science to examine what it truly takes to implement AI at the grassroots. Drawing on real-world case studies and research, the session explores data readiness, ethics, workforce capacity, and system integration needed to responsibly translate AI innovation into equitable health outcomes.
Day 17.Description_3: Center for Global Digital Health Innovation

Day 17.Title: Women at the Frontline of AI: Reimagining Skilling for India's Community Health Workforce
Day 17.Name: Amrita Mahale, ARMMAN
Day 17.name: Ashish Srivastava, AI Innovation for Inclusion Initiative, IIIT Bangalore
Day 17.Description_1: This session examines how AI can strengthen India's women-led community health workforce through inclusive skilling and real-world deployment. Drawing on large-scale use of LLM-powered tools with ASHAs and ANMs across multiple states, the session explores productivity gains, quality of care, and equitable AI access in rural settings. The discussion highlights practical pathways for building a scalable, gender-responsive, AI-enabled frontline workforce in India and globally.

Day 17.Title: AI Compute beyond GPUs
Day 17.Name: Abhishek Biswal, Airtel - Xtelify
Day 17.name: Becky Fraser, Qualcomm
Day 17.name_1: Bhawna Agarwal, Hewlett Packard Enterprise, India
Day 17.name_2: Jason Oxman, Information Technology Industry Council
Day 17.Description_1: This session explores the critical infrastructure powering inclusive AI ecosystems. It will examine compute networking, power, systems design and skills as enablers of innovation and economic growth. Participants will identify infrastructure bottlenecks, discuss pathways to democratize access to hardware and R&D and connect distributed, energy-efficient infrastructure to resilience. Through examples of open innovation and public–private collaboration, the session will generate actionable insights for policymakers and ecosystem builders seeking scalable, equitable AI infrastructure across regions globally.

Day 17.Title: Deep Tech and AI Investing in India: Current and Future States
Day 17.Name: Gopal Jain, Gaja Capital
Day 17.name: Nishith Desai, Nishith Desai & Co.
Day 17.Description_1: India is entering a new phase in its transition towards a product-innovation economy, with deep tech and AI playing an increasingly important role. This panel will launch a report offering a data-driven view of capital flows, funding gaps, and ecosystem maturity. Speakers will examine AI as a horizontal enabler across deep tech sectors and discuss policy and investment priorities to support capital access and innovation at scale.
Day 17.Description_4: Sudhir Sethi, Chiratae Ventures India Advisors

Day 17.Title: Fireside Chat on AI/ML Driven Virtual Immersive Autonomous Personalized Learning
Day 17.Name: Ajith Sundaresh, Fusion Kaapi
Day 17.name: Arvind Kumar, Eisner Amper
Day 17.Description_1: This fireside chat draws from personal insights and experiences of the panel members and Aten Inc.'s AI/ML-driven virtual immersive, autonomous, personalized learning solutions to scale talent development in India, particularly for rural, remote and underserved youth in sectors like AI, Semiconductors, Manufacturing, and Telecom to reflect on the summit's core "Chakras" of Human Capital Inclusion, Safe and Trusted AI, Resilience, Innovation & Efficiency, Science, Democratizing AI Resources, and AI for Growth and Social Good.

Day 17.Title: Data Governance at the Intersection of Digital Public Infrastructure and Artificial Intelligence
Day 17.Name: (Moderator) Prateek Waghre, Tech Global Institute, India
Day 17.name: (Moderator) Prateek Waghre, Tech Global Institute, India
Day 17.name_2: Marianne Diaz Hernandez, Researcher on digital rights expert on digital public infrastructure, Venezuela
Day 17.name_3: Marianne Diaz Hernandez, Researcher on   digital public infrastructure, Venezuela
Day 17.Description_1: Digital public infrastructures (DPIs) such as national digital identity systems, payments rails, data-trust frameworks and shared open datasets are rapidly becoming the foundation for AI  development and deployment. When AI systems are trained on or linked through DPIs, the governance of data becomes critical: who collects data, how it's aggregated, for what purposes, with what safeguards.
Day 17.Description_4: Smriti Parsheera, Lawyer and public policy researcher, India
Day 17.Description_7: Vinicius de Faria Silva, Government of Brazil

Day 17.Title: Diagnosing the Future: AI Transforming Healthcare Systems
Day 17.Name: Dr Krithika Rangarajan, All India Institute of Medical Sciences, Delhi
Day 17.name: Dr Vidur Mahajan, Carpl.ai
Day 17.name_1: Mr Adarsh Srivastava, Roche Diagnostics R&D
Day 17.name_2: Mr Apoorva Patni, Patni Healthcare Ltd.
Day 17.name_3: Mr John W Schaeffler, GE HealthCare Foundation
Day 17.Description_1: Artificial Intelligence is reshaping India's healthcare system, beginning with medical technologies and diagnostics and extending to hospital operations, clinical decision support, research, and preventive care. AI-enabled imaging, IVDs, and analytics are improving accuracy, access, and system efficiency, particularly in resource-constrained settings. This session will examine policy, governance, and collaboration pathways to responsibly scale AI across diagnostics, care delivery and research, supporting a resilient and future-ready healthcare ecosystem
Day 17.Description_4: Shri G. Veerapandian, Health & Family Welfare Department and Mission Director, National Health Mission, Government of Andhra Pradesh
Day 17.Description_7: Shri Kiran Gopal Vaska (IAS), ABDM, National Health Authority, GoI

Day 17.Title: AI in Work: Humans, AI, or Both?
Day 17.Name: David Yanagizawa-Drott, University of Zurich
Day 17.name: Elizabeth Kelly, Anthropic
Day 17.Description_1: How can AI help in enhancing recruitment pipelines to improve efficiency and productivity of firms? This session, featuring a presentation by an international researcher on a randomised evaluation on leveraging AI tools to improve teacher hiring, followed by a panel discussion with leading practitioners. This discussion will examine how AI can reshape recruitment pipelines, skill matching and workforce productivity. Participants will explore how evidence can inform the design and adoption of AI tools that enhance skills, productivity, and worker wellbeing.

Day 17.Title: Investing in Bharat: Regional AI Hubs and Inclusive Growth
Day 17.ROom: Hall No. 5 First Floor - Session Hall 1
Day 17.Name: Sh. Arvind Kumar, Director General, STPI
Day 17.name: Dr. Deepak Bagla,Mission Director AIM, NITI Aayog
Day 17.name_1: Ms. Amneet P. Kumar,  Principal Secretary to the Govt. of Haryana
Day 17.name_2: Sh. Shri Jitendra Kumar, MD, BIRAC, Dept. of Biotechnology
Day 17.Description_1: This session examines how AI is transforming education, industry, and institutions at scale. It will explore borderless learning enabled by AI, industry perspectives on adoption and competitiveness, and the integration of AI with blockchain to rewire institutional systems. The discussion will focus on translating policy intent into practical, secure, and scalable implementations across sectors and ecosystems.

Day 17.Title: Engineering Digital Trust in the Age of AI - Blockchain as the Backbone of India’s Intelligence Infrastructure
Day 17.ROom: Hall No. 4 First Floor - Conference Room 2
Day 17.Name: Dr. Shiv Sharma, BFPF
Day 17.name: Prof. Satya.N.Gupta, BFPF, SAU
Day 17.name_1: Dr. Praveen Mishra, Director ICT, South Asian University (SAU)
Day 17.Description_1: Discover how blockchain can serve as the backbone of India’s intelligence infrastructure—strengthening digital trust in the age of AI. Sessions explore secure data exchange, transparent governance, decentralized identity, and resilient innovation ecosystems, highlighting how incubators, enterprises, and missions can leverage blockchain to ensure integrity, accountability, and sovereignty in India’s AI‑driven future.
Day 17.Description_4: Mr. Anurag Agrawal, Founder & CEO, DataBloc

Day 17.Title: Building India's Most Deployment-Ready AI State: The Tamil Nadu Model (Hosted By Electronics Corporation of Tamil Nadu Limited)
Day 17.ROom: Hall No. 4 First Floor - Session Hall 3
Day 17.Description_1: The session will highlight Tamil Nadu's approach towards operationalising AI at scale, with emphasis on deployment readiness, public infrastructure, and real-world outcomes across sectors.
Day 17.Description_3: Electronics Corporation of Tamil Nadu Limited

Day 17.Title: Tata Bharat YUVAi Hackathon
Day 17.Name: Srividhya Muralidharan, Tata Consultancy Services
Day 17.Description_1:
What happens when 2,000 college students, non-coders, build working apps in just three
hours? Find out in this session, where Arts, Science, and Commerce students will go from picking a real-
world problem to creating a digital prototype, all guided by AI that works in Indian languages. Students
choose challenges across healthcare, education, agriculture, and civic life, then use step-by-step AI tools
to research, brainstorm, and build — no programming experience needed. It's a live demonstration of
what India's next million digital creators could look like.

Day 17.Title: AI Masterclass in Public Services
Day 17.Name: Arun Ramchandran, Tata Consultancy Services
Day 17.name: Sankha Som, Tata Consultancy Services
Day 17.Description_1: This is a practical, hands-on, session, facilitated by Tata Consultancy Services, where participants will build applications in grievance management and welfare scheme eligibility, empowering participants to build their own AI applications with zero coding. This Masterclass will provide participants with a clear framework for developing public sector applications that prioritize AI, responsibility, and data sovereignty. It will also offer an accessible introduction to building practical solutions using large language models through effective prompting techniques.

Day 17.Title: YUVAi: Global Youth Challenge - Grand Finale
Day 17.Name: Sh. Mohammed Y. Safirulla K, Director, IndiaAI Mission, Ministry of Electronics & Information Technology
Day 17.name: Deepak Bagla, Mission Director, Atal Innovation Mission (AIM)
Day 17.name_1: Ivana Bartoletti, Vice-President, Global Chief Privacy and  AI Governance Officer, Wipro (TBC)
Day 17.Description_1: This session will feature presentations by selected teams across three panels, showcasing their ideas and solutions. Each segment will be followed by jury interactions and questions, enabling deeper evaluation, feedback, and discussion.

Day 17.Title: Public Distribution Systems Reforms – AI/ML and Computer Vision for Smart Logistics and Consumer Welfare
Day 17.Name: Aditya, Vexoo Labs
Day 17.name: G Kalyana Chakravarthy, Deloitte, India
Day 17.name_1: Hardik Dave, RoadVision AI Private Limited
Day 17.name_2: Lakshmi Venkat, Real Variable Digital Asset Services Pvt. Ltd.
Day 17.name_3: Nozomi Hashimoto, UN World Food Programme, India
Day 17.Description_1: This session will focus on applications of AI/ML and computer vision in public distribution systems, with emphasis on warehouse monitoring and predictive price intelligence. Drawing on large-scale implementation experiences and perspectives from multilateral institutions, the discussion will examine scalable models, responsible AI frameworks, and financing approaches to support food security and consumer welfare in developing economies.
Day 17.Description_4: Partha Sai Surathu, RNIT AI Solutions Limited
Day 17.Description_7: Shri Nadendla Manohar, Government of Andhra Pradesh

Day 17.Title: AI for Secure India: Combating AI-Enabled Cybercrime, Deepfakes, Darkweb Threats and Data Breaches
Day 17.Name: Deepak Kumar Singh, IIIT Lucknow
Day 17.name: Rakesh Maheshwari, Cyber Law & Data Governance Expert
Day 17.name_1: Sapna Bansal, Shri Ram College of Commerce, University of Delhi
Day 17.name_3: Triveni Singh, Future Crime Research Foundation
Day 17.Description_1: This session by the Future Crime Research Foundation examines how artificial intelligence is reshaping the cyber threat landscape in India. Titled "AI for Secure India: Combating AI-Enabled Cybercrime, Deepfakes, Darkweb Threats & Data Breaches", the discussion will unpack emerging attack vectors, real-world cases, and defensive strategies. Moderated by Prof. Triveni Singh, Ex-IPS officer and Chief Mentor, FCRF, the session focuses on policy, investigation, and resilience across government, enterprises, and law enforcement ecosystems, nationwide stakeholders.
Day 17.Description_4: Vivek Sood, Supreme Court of India

Day 17.Title: Advancing Rural AI Access and Ethical AI Governance
Day 17.Name: Arun Poddar, Piramal Foundation
Day 17.name: Chaula Diwanji, BMC Software
Day 17.Description_1: This initiative focuses on expanding equitable access to artificial intelligence for rural and underserved communities while promoting responsible and ethical AI adoption. By strengthening local capacity through education, digital infrastructure, and teacher enablement, it ensures that AI tools are used transparently, inclusively, and for public good. The approach balances innovation with accountability, empowering communities to leverage AI for learning, livelihoods, and social development without widening existing digital divides.

Day 17.Title: From Policy to Practice: Governing AI for Global Impact
Day 17.Name: Ashish Aggarwal, Nasscom
Day 17.name: Gail Kent, Google
Day 17.name_2: Jules Polonetsky, Future of Privacy Forum
Day 17.Description_1: Trust is the infrastructure of AI adoption. This session focuses on what it takes in 2026 to govern AI for real world benefit, especially in the Global Majority. We move from principles to practice through sandboxes with clear entry and exit criteria, independent evaluation and red teaming, and reusable assurance artifacts such as model cards, audit logs, and incident reporting. We ask where interoperability and collaboration accelerate impact, and where sovereignty and geopolitics create friction.

Day 17.Title: Gyan Bharatam: Where Tradition Meets Technology
Day 17.Name: Prof Vasantkumar M Bhatt, University of Ahmedabad
Day 17.name: Prof. Santanu Chaudhury, IIT Delhi
Day 17.name_1: Prof. Shrinivasa Varakhedi, Central Sanskrit University (CSU)
Day 17.name_3: Shri Inderjeet Singh, Ministry of Culture
Day 17.Description_1:
Gyan Bharatam, a flagship initiative of the Ministry of Culture, is aimed at unearthing, safeguarding, and preserving India's vast manuscript heritage.
The panel discussion will focus on exploring national and global initiatives under the Gyan Bharatam to bridge India's timeless knowledge systems with modern technologies by development and implementation of AI and OCR/HTR solutions for decoding ancient Indian scripts and languages for Large Language Model (LLM) applications and harnessing the power of manuscripts
Day 17.Description_4: Shri Kamlesh Kumar Mishra, Ministry of Culture

Day 17.Title: Frugal AI and Quantum-Ready Systems: Driving Growth, Impact, and the SDGs
Day 17.Name: Anusha Dandapani, UNICC
Day 17.name: Jagadish Babu, EkStep Foundation
Day 17.name_1: Sameer Chauhan, United Nations International Computing Centre
Day 17.name_2: Serish Gandikota, Frugal AI Hub,  Judge Business school, Cambridge University
Day 17.name_3: Sridhar C V, Andhra Pradesh Quantum Mission
Day 17.Description_1: This session explores how cost-efficient and future-ready technologies can drive sustainable growth and social impact. Grounded in practical frameworks for responsible innovation and informed by emerging quantum initiatives, the discussion will focus on affordable AI adoption in the public sector, lifecycle evaluation of advanced technologies, and the development of resilient national digital infrastructure. Participants will examine early preparation for the quantum era and strategies for linking technology deployment to public value and SDG outcomes.
Day 17.Description_3: Frugal AI Hub at Cambridge Judge Business School

Day 17.Title: Pathways for Equitable AI Compute Access
Day 17.Name: Mr. Hector De Rivoire, Microsoft
Day 17.name: Mr. Robert F. Trager, Oxford Martin AI Governance Initiative
Day 17.name_1: Mr. Rohit Kumar, The Quantum Hub
Day 17.name_2: Mr. Sunil Gupta, Yotta Data Services
Day 17.name_3: Ms.  PeiChin Tay, Tony Blair Institute for Global Change
Day 17.Description_1: The session will present a policy framework for a shared compute hub model that entails regionally shared, jointly financed, and transparently governed AI compute infrastructure. It will convene leading policymakers, researchers, and industry experts to discuss the model's viability, financing, and governance, and to use it as a case study to explore an 'equitable compute agenda' as a potential outcome of the India AI Summit 2026.

Day 17.Title: Reducing AI-Driven Digital Harms for Minors: Platform Accountability, Age Assurance, and Safety-by-Design
Day 17.Name: Abhineet Kaul, Access Partnership
Day 17.name: Aleksandra Chmielewska, UNICEF
Day 17.name_1: Kelly Forbes, AI Asia Pacific Institute
Day 17.name_2: Libby Giles, New Zealand Centre for Global Studies
Day 17.name_3: Niki Natrajan, Department at Rutgers, State University of New Jersey
Day 17.Description_1: Over the past decade, digital platforms and AI have transformed how children learn, socialise, and access information, including within schools. While offering benefits, these technologies also heighten risks such as harmful content exposure, harassment, privacy loss, addictive design, and mental health impacts, with generative AI amplifying scale. This panel explores global policy approaches—duty-of-care, age-appropriate design, age assurance, recommender governance, and education safeguards—to balance innovation with stronger online safety for children.

Day 17.Title: AI in Public Health: Bridging Gaps from Pilots to Sustainable Impact
Day 17.Name: Ajay Mahipal, HealthKois
Day 17.name: Himanshu Sikka, IPE Global
Day 17.name_1: Ishita Jain, Maternal, Child Health and Nutrition, Children's Investment Fund Foundation
Day 17.name_2: Mr. CK Mishra, MoHFW & MoEF, GoI,Serum Institute
Day 17.name_3: Mr. Pierrick Fillion Ashida, Research-Innovation, European Union Delegation.
Day 17.Description_1: Aligned with the People and Progress Sutras of the India AI Impact Summit 2026, this session examines the barriers and enablers for integrating AI into public health systems at scale. Anchored in the Chakras of AI for Social Good, Democratizing AI Resources, and Resilient Innovation, it addresses the "missing middle" between pilots and adoption, outlining actionable pathways to embed AI healthcare innovations as durable public infrastructure for the Global South.
Day 17.Description_7: Nitin Vashisht, Indian Oil Corporation Limited

Day 17.Title: Navigating AI-DPI Geopolitics: An Autonomous and Strategic Approach for the Global Majority
Day 17.Name: Dr. Mehdi Snene, UN Office for Digital and Emerging Technologies
Day 17.name: Jane Munga, Carnegie Endowment
Day 17.Description_1: As India and other countries integrate AI into Digital Public Infrastructure (DPI), they confront critical geopolitical challenges related to sovereignty, reducing dependency, and enabling global cooperation—while preserving openness and interoperability. Held alongside the India AI Impact Summit, this session will explore public-interest AI-DPI pathways beyond major power centric technology ecosystems. Drawing on global case studies and expert dialogue, it will examine geopolitical implications, distill lessons for the Global Majority, identify mechanisms for collaboration, and propose recommendations for DPI stakeholders and technology funders for 2026.

Day 17.Title: One Billion Futures: AI and the Future of Education Equity in the Global South
Day 17.Name: Aditya Vishwanath, Makerghat
Day 17.name: Dr.  Shitanshu Mishra, UNESCO MGIEP
Day 17.Description_1: This session explores how responsible AI can bridge the growing learning and digital divides across the Global South, home to 85% of the world's youth. It focuses on leveraging AI to make education more inclusive, accessible, and equitable for underserved communities...
Day 17.Description_4: Vandana Sikka, Code.org and Women in Data Science(WiDS)

Day 17.Title: Great Powers in the Age of AI and Cognitive Systems
Day 17.Name: Mr. Garry Jacobs, The World Academy of Art & Science
Day 17.name: Mr. Glenn Gaffney, NobleReach Foundation, Former CIA Director for Science and Technology
Day 17.name_1: Mr. Ketan Patel, Greater Pacific Capital
Day 17.Description_1: The session will feature the release and presentation of the report "Great Powers in the Age of AI and Cognitive Systems," highlighting key themes on AI's role in global power structures, governance, and long-term societal impact. A moderated panel will explore AI and cognitive systems in shaping a secure, sustainable future; governance transitions from Industrial to Information Age; India's role; and pathways for responsible innovation and equitable growth.

Day 17.Title: Scaling Trusted AI: Global Practices, Local Impact
Day 17.Name: Akanksha Ray, Credo AI
Day 17.name: Candice Anderson, Credo AI
Day 17.Description_1: Join senior industry leaders as they showcase enterprise-scale trusted AI adapted for diverse regulatory and market contexts. Moderated by an AI governance expert, the panel will share real-world governance use cases, metrics for measuring trust across geographies, and cross-sector insights. The discussion will highlight practical tools aligned with frameworks such as India's AI Governance Guidelines and explore how proven governance approaches can be localised to scale trusted AI innovation across emerging markets and varied operational contexts.

Day 17.Title: AI for Resilient India: Driving Innovation and Efficiency at Scale
Day 17.Name: Dr. Gowtham Mamidisetti, St. Martin's Engineering College
Day 17.name: Dr. Prasad Patibandla, Centre for Research on Cyber Intelligence and Digital Forensics(CRCIDF)
Day 17.Description_1: This session explores how artificial intelligence can strengthen national resilience by transforming industries, governance, and digital infrastructure. It highlights the role of AI in driving large-scale innovation, improving operational efficiency, and enabling data-driven decision-making. The discussion will examine scalable AI adoption, enterprise transformation, and cross-sector collaboration, while showcasing real-world applications that accelerate India's journey from experimentation to impactful, production-ready AI solutions.
Day 17.Description_4: Prof. Dr. Kasa Ravindra, St. Martin's Engineering College

Day 17.Title: Quality Control of AI Applications in Healthcare
Day 17.Name: Lt Col Parikshit Sanyal, AFMC Pune
Day 17.name: Nisheeth Srivastava, IIT, Kanpur
Day 17.Description_1: Deploy AI models in healthcare through phased pilots, using clinically validated datasets and bias audits. Establish strict data governance, patient consent, and privacy compliance. Implement human-in-the-loop oversight for all clinical decisions. Mandate regulatory approvals, model explainability, and documentation. Conduct continuous performance monitoring, post-deployment audits, and retraining. Define clear accountability, cybersecurity safeguards, and standardized quality benchmarks to ensure safety, accuracy, transparency, and trust in real-world clinical use.

Day 17.Title: AI Vishwaguru: Catalysing Learning and Impact
Day 17.Name: Abhishek Singh, IAS, IndiaAI Mission, MeitY
Day 17.name: Iqbal Dhaliwal, J-PAL; MIT
Day 17.Description_1: This session will feature the launch of the AI Evidence Playbook, followed by a fireside chat with leaders from civil society and MeitY, Government of India. The discussion will build on the playbook, a practical guide for policymakers and practitioners developing AI-enabled programs, outlining how to identify high-impact use cases and design and evaluate these initiatives. Attendees will receive a digital copy to support the translation of AI policy into practice.

Day 17.Title: From Models to Systems: Rethinking the Evaluation of AI in Health
Day 17.Name: Arjun Venkatraman, Gates Foundation
Day 17.name: Dr. Mona Duggal, ICMR
Day 17.name_1: Dr. Smisha Agarwal, John Hopkins University
Day 17.name_2: Dr. Suruchi Gupta, Center for Global Digital Health Innovation (CGDHI), John Hopkins University
Day 17.Description_1: AI is increasingly being adopted across health systems, but evidence on safe and equitable use remains fragmented and not consistently aligned with decision-making needs. Existing frameworks often prioritise model performance over real-world interactions with digital infrastructure and contextual factors. This panel will examine methodological gaps in digital health research and discuss a more holistic agenda for AI integration, governance, effectiveness, and equity, concluding with a set of recommendations.
Day 17.Description_3: Center for Global Digital Health Innovation
Day 17.Description_7: Sarang Deo, Indian School of Business

Day 17.Title: Culture and Code: Creative AI for Equitable Development
Day 17.Name: . Ms. Siok Siok Tan, Author, Filmmaker & Entrepreneur
Day 17.name: Mr. Shekhar Kapur, Internationally acclaimed filmmaker
Day 17.name_3: Vilas Dhar, The Patrick J. McGovern Foundation
Day 17.Description_1: The session will deliberate on the role of Artificial Intelligence in democratizing creativity and advancing inclusion, while addressing concerns related to authenticity, ethical use, and equity. It will explore how AI can broaden access to creative expression, along with the safeguards needed to ensure its contributions support responsible and inclusive development.

Day 17.Title: Social Empowerment via AI Accessibility
Day 17.ROom: Hall No. 5 First Floor - Session Hall 1
Day 17.Name: Ms. Geeta Goel, Head of Global Growth Initiatives, Michael & Susan Dell Foundation
Day 17.name: Sh. Tarun Adlakha, Founder & Chief Executive, Ashwath Ventures
Day 17.name_1: Sh. Shayak Mazumder, CEO & CTO, Adya
Day 17.Description_1: Explore how accessible AI can empower marginalized communities—covering inclusive design, assistive technologies, low‑bandwidth and local‑language models, community co‑design, and policy frameworks. Sessions highlight scalable solutions, skilling pathways, and cross‑sector partnerships that expand digital participation and economic opportunity.

Day 17.Title: The AI Infrastructure Story: Data Centres and Cloud in Action
Day 17.ROom: Hall No. 3 First Floor - Session Hall 4
Day 17.Name: Sh. Srivenkata Laxminarasimharao Gulimi, Director, STPI-HQ
Day 17.name: Sh. Piyush Somani, Promoter, MD & Chairman, ESDS
Day 17.Description_1: This session explores India’s evolving AI infrastructure stack, from sovereign, secure hyperscale data centres to sustainable cooling, green energy integration, cloud-delivered AI services, and edge computing. It will examine how resilient, energy-efficient, and distributed compute architectures can support India’s AI ambitions while balancing scale, sustainability, security, and accessibility across sectors and geographies.

Day 17.Title: AI for the Global South: From Governance to Inclusion
Day 17.Name: Ambassador  Dr. Lavina Ramkissoon, African Union-ASRIC
Day 17.name: Ambassador Eugênio Vargas Garcia, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Brazil
Day 17.name_1: Dr. Sasmit Patra, Rajya Sabha, India
Day 17.name_2: S. Niranjan Reddy, Rajya Sabha, India
Day 17.name_3: Trisha Ray, Geo-Tech Center, Atlantic Council
Day 17.Description_1: This high-level roundtable convenes parliamentarians, diplomats, multilateral organizations, and technology governance experts to facilitate a strategic dialogue on shaping an inclusive global AI agenda rooted in the developmental priorities of the Global South. Participants will explore frameworks for multilateral cooperation and examine how legislative and regulatory ecosystems can encourage responsible AI innovation in critical domains including healthcare, agriculture, education, and social protection, ensuring that AI adoption broadly supports equitable access and drives inclusive development.

Day 17.Title: US-India Coordination on Cyber Security and Resilience
Day 17.Name: Mr Hari Jayaram, Applied Material
Day 17.name: Mr. Abhijeet Gogoi, Zinnov
Day 17.name_1: Mr. Dr Vivek Singh, NITI Aayog, GoI
Day 17.Description_1: The US-India cybersecurity alliance is a vital partnership between the world's leading democracies. With India's digital infrastructure heavily reliant on American technology, coordinated resilience is essential. As AI redefines security, the focus shifts to AI for Cyber—enhancing threat detection—and Cyber for AI—securing AI systems. By building shared frameworks, both nations can protect critical infrastructure, foster innovation, and ensure AI remains a trustworthy foundation for the global digital economy.
Day 17.Description_3: The American Chamber of Commerce in India (AMCHAM India)
Day 17.Description_4: Mr. John W Schaeffler, Government affairs & Policy GE
Day 17.Description_7: Mr. K K Singh, Meity, GoI

Day 17.Title: Flipping the Script: How the Global Majority Can Recode the AI Economy
Day 17.Name: Kazim Rizvi, The Dialogue
Day 17.name: Philip Thigo, Republic of Kenya
Day 17.name_1: Rachel Adams, Global Center on AI Governance
Day 17.Description_1: This session will examine how countries in the Global Majority can reshape the AI economy by moving from adoption to agency. It will explore practical pathways for ethical, inclusive, and economically viable AI ecosystems. Through policy dialogue and audience exchange, the discussion will highlight data governance, infrastructure, talent, and standards as levers of sovereignty, and will outline concrete models for South–South cooperation to build resilient, value-sharing AI futures.

Day 17.Title: Teacher-Led, Localised and Frugal AI for Equitable Education in the Commonwealth
Day 17.Name: Dr Basheerhamad Shadrach, Commonwealth Educational Media Centre for Asia
Day 17.name: Dr Edwin Tarno, Kenya School of TVET, Government of Kenya
Day 17.name_1: Dr Rajni Kaushal Chand, Centre for Flexible Learning, University of the South Pacific
Day 17.name_2: Dr Sawkat Rojid, Minister of Education, Mauritius
Day 17.Description_1: This session presents practical pathways for "Teacher-in-the-Loop" AI and localized, open-source LLM deployments. Commonwealth ministers and leaders will examine policy, capacity, and governance to enable frugal, sovereign, and inclusive AI in education, specifically for lower-resource settings. Key outcomes include identifying pilot collaborations, publishing a sovereign education-AI reference architecture, and establishing monitorable indicators for 12-month follow-up.
Day 17.Description_4: Dr The Honourable Ismail Shafeeu, Education, Maldives
Day 17.Description_7: Prof. Ganesan Kannabiran, National Assessment and Accreditation Council (NAAC)

Day 17.Title: Local Voices First: Why Inclusive AI for Data Systems Must Start on the Ground
Day 17.Name: Amitabh Nag, Digital India Bhashini
Day 17.name: Gaurav Godhwani, CivicDataLab
Day 17.Description_1: The session examines how AI can better serve citizens when grounded in local data ecosystems, languages, and institutional realities. Through expert insights, it highlights co-created, inclusive AI as public infrastructure for official statistics, featuring innovations from the Global South and national institutions. The panel discussion shows how locally rooted approaches enhance relevance, legitimacy, and trust in data-driven governance, strengthening evidence-based policymaking and responsive public services.

Day 17.Title: Building India's AI Governance Architecture: From Frameworks to Implementation
Day 17.Name: Abhishek Singh, Meity, GoI
Day 17.name: Abhishek Singh, MeitY, GOI
Day 17.Description_1: This session will explore how India can build mission driven institutions to govern artificial intelligence at national scale. It will examine emerging approaches to AI governance and expert mechanisms, drawing lessons from successful public digital institutions. The discussion will focus on balancing innovation with accountability, clarifying institutional mandates, and enabling sustained collaboration across government, industry, startups, and research to translate AI strategy into effective, responsible execution.

Day 17.Title: The Sociotechnical Turn in AI Governance: Bridging Theory and Practice
Day 17.Name: Dr. Siddharth Mehrotra, University of Amsterdam & ICAI
Day 17.name: H.E. Hendrikus G.J. (Harry) Verweij, Kingdom of the Netherlands
Day 17.name_1: Kirthi Jayakumar, Inclusive AI Lab, Utrecht University
Day 17.name_2: Lisa Gotoh, Kingdom of the Netherlands
Day 17.name_3: Prof. Maarten de Rijke, University of Amsterdam & ICAI
Day 17.Description_1: This session will explore how sociotechnical approaches to artificial intelligence can move from theory to real-world governance practice. It will examine how social context, power, trust, and institutional design shape AI risks and outcomes beyond purely technical solutions. Bringing together research and practice, the discussion will focus on translating sociotechnical insights into actionable frameworks for safe and trusted AI, with particular relevance for public sector deployment and Global South contexts.
Day 17.Description_4: Prof. Virginia Dignum, Civic AI Lab, ICAI & Umeå Universitet, Sweden

Day 17.Title: Governing Autonomy: Agentic AI, Multi-Agent Systems, and the Infrastructure of Trust
Day 17.Name: Alpesh Shah, IEEE Standards
Day 17.name: Amir Banifatemi, Cognizant
Day 17.Description_1: This session will be focused on addressing governance gaps in emerging agentic and multi-agent AI systems. The session will introduce a new public–private governance framework and showcase the Agentic AI Governance Stack through a live demonstration, followed by expert's discussion on safe autonomy, accountability, and standards. It will conclude with the launch of a global Agentic AI Testbed, inviting multi-stakeholder collaboration led by India's DPI strengths.
Day 17.Description_3: Cognizant - Responsible AI Office and AI Lab
Day 17.Description_4: Ramesh Raskar, Massachusetts Institute of Technology

Day 17.Title: AI-Driven Digital Transformation for India: Building Innovation an Ecosystem through Collaboration
Day 17.Name: Abhilash Soundararajan, PrivaSapien
Day 17.name: Akhil Gupta, Convozen AI and NoBrokerHood
Day 17.Description_1: This session brings together leaders from government, industry, startups, and academia to discuss democratizing AI infrastructure for innovation. The session explores how accessible AI infrastructure can empower startups, MSMEs, and researchers, and how collaborative national models can sustain growth. It highlights the value of open repositories, shared use cases across sectors, and open-source platforms, while emphasizing ethical, inclusive AI design that prioritizes privacy, fairness and accessibility to help India lead global AI innovation.

Day 17.Title: Democratizing AI Resources in India
Day 17.Name: Dr. Chris Merz, Mastercard
Day 17.name: Dr. Lovneesh Chanana, ASSOCHAM IT/ ITeS Council and SAP ASIA Pte Ltd
Day 17.name_1: Mahaveer Singhvi, Ministry of External Affairs, Govt. of India
Day 17.name_3: Manoj Paul, Equinix India and ASSOCHAM National Datacenter Council
Day 17.Description_1: As India emerges as a regional AI leader in South Asia, this session will explore how business-driven AI, combined with India's digital public infrastructure, startup innovation and cloud-led transformation, can deliver inclusive and commercially viable social impact. The discussion will highlight how scalable AI adoption across SMEs and startups can democratise resources, expand access to services, create equitable opportunities, and showcase India's model of cross-border collaboration, inclusive use cases and knowledge sharing for sustainable growth.
Day 17.Description_3: The Associated Chambers of Commerce & Industry of India (ASSOCHAM)
Day 17.Description_4: Mr. Sunil Gupta, Yotta & Co- Chair and ASSOCHAM AI Task Force

Day 17.Title: Reskilling for Tomorrow: AI, Sustainability, and India's Jobs Transition
Day 17.Name: Dr Arunabha Ghosh, Council on Energy, Environment and Water (CEEW)
Day 17.name: Dr Claire Melamed, UN Foundation
Day 17.name_1: Mr Nirmit Parikh, Apna Jobs and Bluemachines AI
Day 17.Description_1: India's move toward a green and digital economy is reshaping jobs, skills, and employer expectations. This panel examines how AI and automation can support skill mapping, personalised training, and workforce transitions—while addressing challenges of access, trust, and inequality. Policymakers, industry, training providers, and technology experts will discuss how India can prepare workers for emerging green and tech-enabled roles and build inclusive, future-ready skilling systems.
Day 17.Description_3: Council on Energy Environment and Water (CEEW)

Day 17.Title: Founders & Funders: The India AI Capital Ecosystem
Day 17.Name: ⁠⁠Aakrit Vaish, Activate
Day 17.name: Mohit Bhatnagar, Peak XV
Day 17.name_2: S. Krishnan, Ministry of Electronics & IT, GoI
Day 17.Description_1: The session will convene senior policymakers, global investors, and leading AI architects to discuss India's roadmap for building AI for the world. Conversations will span the full stack—from compute and semiconductor foundations to the "AI Alpha" that guides frontier investment decisions. The dialogue will focus on designing foundational models and scaling India's intelligence infrastructure for global impact. From silicon to superintelligence, the session will chart India's pathway to long-term AI leadership.

Day 17.Title: Voice as the Default Interface for India's Next Billion Users
Day 17.Name: Ananth Nagaraj, Gnani.ai
Day 17.name: Chinmaya Sharma, InfoEdge Ventures
Day 17.Description_1: India's next billion digital users require voice-first interfaces to overcome literacy, language, and digital literacy barriers that exclude 100s of millions from existing text-based systems. This panel examines how multilingual, emotion-aware voice AI can enable transactions, from banking to healthcare, in native languages on low-end devices. Discussions cover technical requirements for handling code-switching and noisy environments, orchestration with backend systems, enterprise cost reduction, and policy frameworks needed to build inclusive voice-first digital infrastructure at scale.

Day 17.Title: AI in Climate and Agriculture: Building Resilient Communities
Day 17.Name: George Richards, Jameel
Day 17.name: Maulik Jagnani, Tufts University
Day 17.Description_1: How can AI based technologies strengthen climate resilience and reduce impacts of climate shocks for vulnerable households? This session, featuring a presentation by an international researcher on findings from a randomised evaluation of the impact of AI-based flood Early Warning Systems (EWS), followed by a panel discussion with leading experts. Building on this evidence, panellists explore how rigorously evaluated AI applications can support effective climate adaptation strategies, improve preparedness, and translate technological innovations into accelerating climate action.

Day 17.Title: AI Masterclass in Enterprise Operations
Day 17.Name: Vasant Srinivasan, Tata Communications
Day 17.Description_1: This session, facilitated by Tata Communications, is focused on guiding participants from isolated AI initiatives to the implementation of secure, scalable AI solutions across their enterprise operations. Designed for technology and transformation leaders, this hands-on workshop enables participants to design and deploy a fully functional AI Worker using the Tata Communications Agent Builder platform, providing them with direct experience and a practical framework for integrating AI into their enterprise workflows.

Day 17.Title: Decisions at Speed: How Data Intelligence Powers Sovereign and Enterprise AI (Hosted by DataDirect Networks)
Day 17.ROom: Hall No. 4 First Floor - Session Hall 3
Day 17.Name: Sh. Sunil Gupta, CEO, Yotta
Day 17.name: Sh. Atul Vidwansa, Vice President, Sales (Worldwide NCP & AI Cloud Providers)
Day 17.name_1: Sh. Vishal Dhupar, Managing Director, Asia South at NVIDIA (OR) Anissh Pandey, Global Segment Lead - NVIDIA CLOUD PARTNER ( NCP)
Day 17.Description_1: As AI shifts from experimentation to deployment, the ability to rapidly convert data into decisions becomes a strategic advantage, with insight latency emerging as a key constraint. This session by DDN examines how high-performance data intelligence strengthens infrastructure for Sovereign and Enterprise AI in India, enabling faster training, real-time analytics, and scalable decision-making. Through showcases, customer insights, and Indian case examples, it highlights building responsive, reliable, production-ready AI systems.

Day 17.Title: Global Capital, Local Advantage: India in the AI Race
Day 17.Name: Sriram Viswanathan
Day 17.name: Abhishek Shukla
Day 17.Description_1: India’s AI opportunity is global: products can be built locally and sold worldwide, but leadership depends on translating India’s strengths-talent, digital infrastructure, and cost-efficient execution-into scalable applications. This session spotlights where India can lead across the AI value chain, focusing on sectors like financial services and insurance, where AI transforms underwriting, claims, and risk. It will examine sovereign AI-autonomy in models, data, and compute-and how cross-domain investments can accelerate India’s advantage.

Day 17.Title: AI in Financial services - From Innovation to Impact
AI in Healthcare for India
Day 17.Name: Dr Catharina Boehme, WHO-SEARO
Day 17.name: Dr Sunil Kumar Barnwal, National Health Authority
Day 17.name_1: Mr Kiran Gopal Vaska, National Health Authority
Day 17.name_2: Ms Punya Salila Srivastava, Ministry of Health and Family Welfare
Day 17.Description_3: Ministry of Health and Family Welfare
Day 17.Description_4: Shri J P Nadda, Government of India

Day 17.Title: The India AI Stack- Strategic Framework for National Growth and Pride
Day 17.Name: Col. Amit Mehna, Indian Army
Day 17.name: Commander Sandeep Sain, Indian Air Force
Day 17.Description_1: This panel explores the India AI Stack across five interdependent layers—Applications, Foundation Models, Chips, Hardware, and Energy—examining how key sectors such as defence, research and education, and geospatial services generate value within India's unique constraints of scale, diversity, sovereignty, security, and power availability. Anchored in the vision of the India AI Impact Summit 2026 and the IndiaAI Mission, the discussion bridges policy intent with practical, nation-scale AI implementation for People, Planet, and Progress.

Day 17.Title: AI Commons for the Global South: Data, Models and Compute for Half of Humanity
Day 17.Name: Amanda Brock, Open UK
Day 17.name: Jayesh Ranjan, Government of Telangana
Day 17.Description_1: AI infrastructure, encompassing compute, data, and models, will determine who is able to build, deploy, and govern AI over the coming decade. At present, access to these foundational resources remains uneven and highly concentrated, constraining meaningful participation across much of the Global South. This session, organised by Factly and Meta, examines how an AI Commons can be developed through shared compute frameworks, AI-ready open data systems, and interoperable model and tooling ecosystems aligned with globally recognised standards.

Day 17.Title: AI for All: Catalysing Jobs, Growth, and Opportunity
Day 17.Name: Aastha Grover, Prosus | Naspers Group
Day 17.name: Ashok Gulati, ICRIER, Comptroller and Auditor General of India, RBI, NABARD and NCDEX
Day 17.name_1: Chandrashekhar Rentala, Centre for the Digital Future, GOI (IT & Telecom) and  NASSCOM
Day 17.Description_1: The session will explore how India's DPI-led approach can enable inclusive AI adoption, unlock job creation, accelerate economic growth, and foster cross-sector collaboration. By bridging policy intent with on-ground execution, the dialogue aims to identify key enablers—policy frameworks, industry participation, and startup innovation—required to scale AI responsibly and equitably across sectors.
Day 17.Description_4: Manit Jain, The Heritage School and FICCI Arise

Day 17.Title: Leveraging AI in Education: Human Capital, Inclusion, and Trust in the AI Era.
Day 17.Name: Ajit Chauhan, Amity Education Group
Day 17.name: Dr. Prabina Rajib, Birla Institute of Management Technology (BIMTECH)
Day 17.name_1: Dr. Subhajyoti Ray, Jaipuria Insitute of Management, Noida.
Day 17.Description_1: This panel discussion explores how artificial intelligence is reshaping education, with a focus on human capital development, inclusion, and trust. Panelists will reflect on the opportunities AI presents for improving access and learning outcomes, while also addressing concerns around bias, governance, and public confidence. Drawing on policy, practice, and lived experience, the discussion aims to highlight practical insights on aligning AI adoption in education with inclusive and socially trusted outcomes.
Day 17.Description_7: Shreevats Jaipuria, Jaipuria Insitute of Management

Day 17.Title: AI for Medical Imaging and Clinical Diagnostics
Day 17.Name: Dr. Alok Sharma, Nephropathology & EM, Dr. Lal PathLabs Ltd., New Delhi
Day 17.name: Dr. Kundan Singh Chufal, Radiation Oncology Rajiv Gandhi Cancer Institute & Research Centre, Delhi
Day 17.name_1: Prof. Chandan J. Das, Department of Radiodiagnosis & Interventional Radiology All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS), New Delhi
Day 17.name_2: Prof. M. K. Dutta, Amity Centre for Artificial Intelligence (ACAI), Amity University, Noida
Day 17.name_3: Prof. Nidhi Goel, Department of ECE Indira Gandhi Delhi Technical University for Women, Delhi
Day 17.Description_1: The AI for Medical Imaging and Clinical Diagnostics session at the India AI Impact Summit 2026 will explore how AI is transforming healthcare diagnostics. The expert panel will discuss advances in medical imaging, real-world clinical deployment, precision and predictive diagnostics, and responsible AI practices. The session brings together clinicians, AI researchers, and policymakers to strengthen India's healthcare AI ecosystem.
Day 17.Description_4: Prof. Sujeet Gautam, Department of Anaesthesiology SGPGIMS, Lucknow

Day 17.Title: Faculty Futures 2035: Global Roadmap for Human-Centred AI Education
Day 17.Name: Dr. Aigerim (Aia) Shilibekova, University Canada West, CANADA
Day 17.name: Dr. Amandeep Sehmi, Canterbury Institute of Management
Day 17.name_1: Dr. Amit Kumar Mishra, Chandigarh University Uttar Pradesh
Day 17.name_2: Dr. Pranil Prasad, Canterbury Institute of Management
Day 17.name_3: Dr. Sana Jamil, University Canada West, CANADA
Day 17.Description_1:
As AI reshapes teaching, assessment, and governance, higher education faces a
shared challenge: preparing faculty for ethical, inclusive, and human-centered
engagement. Following pre-summit workshops conducted in Canada, Australia,
and India, the Faculty Futures 2035 panel convenes partners at the India AI Impact
Summit 2026 to synthesize insights, surface cross-context lessons, and present a
forward-looking roadmap to guide institutional strategy for the decade ahead.
Day 17.Description_4: Dr. Sandra Song, University Canada West, CANADA
Day 17.Description_7: Dr. Thipendra P Singh, Chandigarh University Uttar Pradesh

Day 17.Title: AI for Humanity as SDG#18: Towards Global and Sustainable Development of AI with Impact
Day 17.Name: Dr. James Ong, Artificial Intelligence International Institute (AIII)
Day 17.name: Judith Weinberger-Singh, Hanns Seidel Foundation India
Day 17.name_1: Maya Sherman, Embassy of Israel in India, GPAI-OECD
Day 17.name_2: Sameer Gahlot, National Internet Exchange of India
Day 17.name_3: Tan Siok Siok, Filmmaker and Entrepreneur
Day 17.Description_1: This session advances the concept of "AI for Humanity" as the invisible SDG 18, recognizing AI as a cross-cutting enabler of all Sustainable Development Goals. Building on previous discussions, it brings global experts together to explore human-centered, inclusive, and sustainable AI frameworks. Through keynotes and panel dialogue, the session aims to reinforce global collaboration and sustain impact beyond 2026 via policy, practice, and multistakeholder engagement.

Day 17.Title: Inclusion for Social Empowerment
Day 17.Name: Mr. Aditya Swam, Google
Day 17.name: Mr. Akhil Choudhary, Highspring India
Day 17.name_1: Mr. Amith Singhee, IBM Research Labs
Day 17.name_2: Mr. Clas Neumann, Global Head of Labs Network
Day 17.Description_1: This session explores how India's AI leadership can move beyond innovation to deliver inclusive social-economic outcomes across South Asia by replicating India's digital public infrastructure, enterprise AI adoption, startup ecosystem through cross-border collaboration and knowledge sharing. It positions AI for All as scalable, impact-first, commercially viable business model for 1.4 billion people, driven by frugal AI solutions for basic smartphones, local languages, low-connectivity networks, catalyzing financial inclusion, healthcare access, skills development, rural productivity, regional social empowerment.
Day 17.Description_3: The Associated Chambers of Commerce & Industry of India (ASSOCHAM)
Day 17.Description_4: Mr. Karthik Rajaram, India Elevan Labs

Day 17.Title: Driving Financial Resilience and Sustainable Impact - AI by and for the Global Majority
Day 17.Name: Dr. Alaa Murabit, 500 Global
Day 17.name: Dr. Michael Kremer, University of Chicago
Day 17.Description_1: While the world focuses on the technical capabilities of AI, we are largely overlooking the financial architecture required to sustain it. Meaningful scale in health and agriculture cannot happen unless we position financial resilience as an equal pillar of success. This panel will discuss how governments, investors, philanthropies, the private sector and technology leaders can align capital and innovation pathways to ensure AI delivers lasting impact.

Day 17.Title: Decoded: How AI Is Reshaping Work for Women
Day 17.Name: Atul Satija, The/Nudge Institute
Day 17.name: Dr. M M Tripathi, NIELIT, MeitY
Day 17.Description_1: This panel will examine the intersection of AI, gender, and the future of work, within evolving digital economies. The discussion will explore gendered impacts of AI while highlighting design, governance, and workforce strategies that consider women's lived experiences and inform policy-relevant pathways toward inclusive, AI-enabled growth. Building on emerging insights from skilling initiatives, the session will focus on identifying pathways where AI can expand decent work and economic security for women at scale.
Day 17.Description_3: GxD hub, LEAD at Krea University
Day 17.Description_4: Sharon Buteau, LEAD at Krea University

Day 17.Title: AI for Societal Good: Global Nonprofit Innovations
Day 17.Name: M R. Rangaswami, Indiaspora
Day 17.name: Manu Chopra, Karya
Day 17.name_2: Mr. Vilas Dhar, Patrick J. McGovern Foundation
Day 17.Description_1: Join leaders from social impact focused AI initiatives to explore how AI is redesigning global systems. Moving beyond theory, this session spotlights evidence-based nonprofit models advancing equity and justice. Attendees will gain actionable insights into funding and scaling community-centered AI that prioritizes human dignity over automation. This session explores the cross-sector collaborations necessary to build a responsible, high-impact AI future for philanthropists and technologists alike.

Day 17.Title: Consumers at the Core: Building AI with Consumer-Centric Approach
Day 17.Name: Mr. Ashim Sanyal, Consumer VOICE
Day 17.name: Mr. Kaushal Mahan, Chase Advisors
Day 17.name_1: Mr. Rohit Kumar Singh, Ministry of Consumer Affairs, Food and Public Distribution, GoI
Day 17.name_3: Ms. Anindita Mehta, Consumer Education and Research Centre
Day 17.Description_1: AI has seen rapid evolution from being a technological tool for consumers performing simple tasks to generative AI with predictive and prescriptive power. Developing AI technologies with a consumer-centric approach is crucial for building consumer trust, inclusion and satisfaction. The panel discussion, 'Consumers at the Core: Building AI with a Consumer-Centric Approach', will focus on the evolving AI ecosystem, the concerns and innovation possibilities of AI with a focus on protecting consumer interest.
Day 17.Description_7: Ms. Sarita Chauhan, Department of Administrative Reforms and Public Grievances, GoI

Day 17.Title: AI in Education: Customising Learning for All
Day 17.Name: Azeez Gupta, Rocket Learning
Day 17.name: Brigitte Hoyer Gosselink, AI and Social Impact
Day 17.Description_1: How can we use AI tools to improve educational outcomes? This session, featuring a presentation by an international researcher followed by a panel discussion with experts, showcases results from a UNESCO prize winning randomised study in Brazil evaluating the impact of an AI-powered essay-grader on students' writing outcomes. Eminent panelists, including a Yidan-laureate, will discuss how evidence can guide the use of AI into tailored instruction, parent engagement, and high-impact educational practices to strengthen learning systems and improve student outcomes.

Day 17.Title: Multi-Stakeholder Collaboration to Foster AI Adoption in the Global South
Day 17.Name: Aisha Walcott-Bryant, Google Research Africa
Day 17.name: Dame Wendy Hall, University of Southampton
Day 17.name_1: Vukosi Marivate, University of Pretoria South Africa
Day 17.Description_1: This session explores the practical and governance dimensions of Responsible AI, focusing on how multi-stakeholder collaboration can accelerate its responsible and inclusive adoption across the Global South. It will highlight actionable frameworks for public-private partnerships, capacity building, ethical governance, and equitable access to AI. Bringing together policymakers, practitioners, researchers, and experts, the session will examine real-world challenges and demonstrate how to implement Responsible AI across critical sectors such as healthcare, education, finance, and law.

Focus points will be on driving advancements in forecasting and logistics, boosting efficiency and automation, and enhancing product quality across the entire value chain.

Day 17.name: Pooja Gulrajani, Consumer Payments, PhonePe

Day 17.Name: David Zapolsky, Amazon
Day 17.name: Kanishka Narayan, United Kingdom

The discussion will explore policy insights and lessons on meeting the adoption challenge, examining how regulatory environments act as both enablers and barriers to innovation as AI moves rapidly.

Day 17.Name: Antara Lahiri, Micron Foundation
Day 17.name: Bhomik Shah, CSRBOX
Day 17.Description_1: This strategic session advances the IndiaAI Mission's vision of AI for People, Planet, and Prosperity through inclusive, human-centered implementation. Built on two years of engagement, pilots, and practitioner insights, it converts intent into impact via commitments, scalable models, and partnerships. The discussion will focus on AI workforce readiness, large-scale faculty capacity building, and institutional readiness to integrate AI systems, infrastructure, and governance.

Day 17.Name: Dr Mukesh Kestwal, IIT Ropar (iHub – AWaDH)
Day 17.name: Dr Pushpendra Singh, IIT Ropar (iHub – AWaDH and Annam.AI Foundation)

It will open with strategic context on cross-border execution and talent mobility. The discussion will then highlight how AI talent becomes execution-ready through workcation and immersion models, alongside real startup and MSME impact cases. It will conclude with key insights, defined stakeholder roles, and clear pathways for post-summit ecosystem collaboration.

Day 17.Description_7: Shri Sanjeev Arora, Government of Punjab

Campus-to-Impact: Building India's AI Innovation Pipeline

Day 17.name: Dr. Nikhil Agarwal, FITT IIT Delhi

Through structured dialogue featuring leaders from academia, industry, government, and international ecosystems, the session identifies scalable collaboration models, documents key challenges, and generates actionable policy recommendations. Live demonstrations by TMIF-incubated startups showcase successful campus-to-market journeys, highlighting how academic institutions can effectively contribute to India's AI innovation pipeline and create tangible real-world impact.

This session aims to bridge the gap between startups building at the frontier and infrastructure development. The conversation will include discussion on how India is building a "full-stack" future, including compute roadmap, how the ISM is strengthening the supply chain for the next generation of AI-first startups, and importance of compute capacity and semiconductors.

Participants will explore AI readiness frameworks, co-design skill metrics for frontline health workers and healthcare providers, and evaluate assessment methods. The session concludes with practical recommendations for scalable, context-aware digital skills measurement across regional and national health workforces.

Outcomes include an end-to-end AI blueprint, sovereign AI frameworks, and high-ROI GenAI use cases across finance, healthcare, energy, telecom, and government.

Day 18.name: Raghu Dharmaraju, ARTPARK

Panelists discuss how researchers, startups, and SMEs leverage platforms like NVIDIA's Isaac and Omniverse to build resource-optimized manufacturing ecosystems. Innovation and workforce upskilling create high-value jobs, ensuring sustainable, inclusive industrial growth across India. It will also consider how scaling AI deployment can contribute to inclusive outcomes and wider participation across sectors.

This panel brings leaders on the front lines of AI transformation to unpack how operating models are evolving. The conversation will explore approaches to AI quality, governance and metrics, global feedback loops, and human-AI workflows that deliver results while embedding AI skills and novel ways of working.

warning, and coordinated response. Participants will discuss institutional designs —from shared taxonomies to secure

Day 18.Description_1: A deep dive into AI's fintech evolution, from automation to intelligence, enabling smarter decisions, scalable innovation, risk resilience, personalization, and transformative impact across financial ecosystems.
Day 18.Description_7: Prof Dipak Gupta, Mehta School of Management, IIT Bombay

Day 18.Title: Governing Safe and Responsible AI within Digital Public Infrastructure
Day 18.Name: Alexandria Walden, Google
Day 18.name: H E Alar Karis, Republic of Estonia
Day 18.name_1: H E Harry Verweij, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, The Kingdom of the Netherlands
Day 18.name_2: H.E. Bernard Maissen, Head of the Federal Office for Communications, Switzerland
Day 18.Description_1: This session will explore safe and responsible AI in Digital Public Infrastructure (DPI), with a focus on algorithmic transparency, human-centred governance, regulatory best practices, and inclusion, including perspectives from the Global South. Distinguished speakers from government, civil society, and industry will offer brief remarks, followed by a moderated discussion and audience Q&A.
Day 18.Description_3: Freedom Online Coalition - Task Force on Artificial Intelligence and Human Rights
Day 18.Description_7: Norman Schulz, Federal Foreign Office, Germany

Day 18.Title: Charting India's AI–IP Playbook: Innovation, Rights and National Advantage
Day 18.Name: Anne E. Robinson, IBM
Day 18.name: Dr. Shardul S. Shroff, Shardul Amarchand Mangaldas & Co
Day 18.name_2: Nitin Seth, Incedo
Day 18.Description_1: From AI-generated content and code to foundation models, traditional boundaries of authorship, inventorship, and ownership are increasingly contested as jurisdictions adapt their intellectual property regimes. The IndiaAI Mission positions indigenous datasets, models, and compute infrastructure as strategic national assets for innovation, exports, and long-term economic growth. Without a future-ready AI–IP framework, India risks legal uncertainty that could constrain innovation and investment. This session situates AI–IP policy within the vision of Viksit Bharat, linking science and innovation, safe and trusted AI, and AI-led economic growth and social good.
Day 18.Description_7: Sabeen Malik, Rapid7

Day 18.Title: How AI Will Reshape Global Development Beyond the SDGs
Day 18.Name: Amandeep Singh Gill, UN ODET
Day 18.name: Kamal Kishore, UN Secretary-General for Disaster Risk Reduction
Day 18.name_2: Paula Bogantes Zamora, Ministery of Science, Innovation, Technology and Telecommunications Costa Rica
Day 18.Description_1: As the 2030 deadline approaches amid economic, social, and geopolitical pressures, this session reframes global development as a structural transformation already underway. Artificial intelligence is reshaping growth models, public institutions, and human capital beyond the SDGs, raising questions about financing, governance, and delivery. Bringing together leaders from finance, philanthropy, technology, and government, the discussion explores how AI can boost productivity, strengthen capacity, unlock development pathways, and mitigate inequality globally equitably.
Day 18.Description_3: United Nations Office for Digital and Emerging Technologies
Day 18.Description_7: Vilas Dhar, Patrick J. McGovern Foundation

Day 18.Title: Responsible AI at Scale, Governance, Integrity, and Cyber Readiness for a Changing World
Day 18.Name: Dr. Balaravindran, CeRAI - IIT Madras
Day 18.name: Dr. Subi Chaturvedi, InMobi
Day 18.name_2: Prof. (Dr.) G.S. Bajpai, National Law University Delhi
Day 18.Description_1: The session aims to develop a practical and inclusive framework for responsible AI adoption at scale, with a focus on governance mechanisms, content integrity safeguards, and cyber resilience. It will position India as a global standard setter for safe and trusted AI that is adaptable to diverse cultural, economic, and institutional contexts, particularly across the Global South. The discussion will generate actionable insights and policy-relevant recommendations that directly contribute to the objectives and outcomes.

Day 18.Title: The Intelligent City: Building Resilient and Inclusive Urban Futures
Day 18.Name: Anshul Mishra, AIIMS Delhi
Day 18.name: Jumbi Edulbehram, Nvidia
Day 18.name_2: Ujjwal Kumar, Quantum Alliance
Day 18.Description_1: This panel examines how AI reshapes urban infrastructure addressing rapid urbanization across the Global South. Leaders with experience in  aviation, energy, water management, and governance explore deploying intelligent systems. The conversation covers how computer vision, predictive analytics, and IoT optimize resource consumption and improve citizen services. Panelists discuss data integration challenges, public-private collaboration, and building technical capacity. This advances the Planet and Progress Sutras through the AI for Economic Growth and Social Good Chakra.

Day 18.Title: Use of AI for Disaster Resilient Infrastructure
Day 18.Name: Dr. Manabendra Saharia, IIT Delhi
Day 18.name: Dr. Pradeep Thapliyal, Space Application Centre, ISRO
Day 18.name_1: Dr. Srikanta K Panigrah, Indian Institute of Sustainable Development (IISD)
Day 18.name_2: Mr. Anshu Sharma, SEEDS
Day 18.Description_1: The session will advance a policy focused understanding of the role of artificial intelligence in strengthening the resilience of critical infrastructure systems with emphasis on capacities to absorb disruptions, respond effectively, and recover sustainably. It will present sectoral evidence on AI-enabled resilience in transport, power and water systems, identify governance, standards and institutional capacity requirements and assess technology options and trade-offs for adoption in low-resource and climate-vulnerable contexts.
Day 18.Description_7: Ms. Rita Missal, NDMA

Day 18.Title: Workforce Readiness for Artificial Intelligence in Primary Health Care
Day 18.Name: Dr Mona Duggal, ICMR
Day 18.name: Dr Monika Kochar, Health, DAKSHIN, RIS
Day 18.name_2: Dr Smisha Agarwal, Center for Global Digital Health Innovation, Johns Hopkins University
Day 18.name_3: Dr Titipol Phakdeewanich, Regional Center for Human Rights, Faculty of Political Science, Ubon Ratchathani University, Thailand
Day 18.Description_1: Digital health innovations and AI are reshaping triage, diagnosis, and population health management, but their impact on primary health care depends on whether frontline workers across cadres can adopt these tools safely, ethically, and effectively. This panel brings together senior experts from government, academia, industry, and think tanks to define AI readiness for primary health care and translate it into role-based competency pathways and practical implementation levers.
Day 18.Description_3: Center for Global Digital Health Innovation
Day 18.Description_4: Professor Anurag Agrawal, Biosciences and Health Research, Ashoka University
Day 18.Description_7: Professor Fuad, Embassy of the Republic of Indonesia, New Delhi
